misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem than specified
misconceptions.description: Instead of writing a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0–100) and outputs a letter grade (A–F), the student implemented a distance-between-two-points calculator. No parts of the required grade classification logic appear in the code.
misconceptions.student_belief: If I write a correct Java program that solves a problem (here: computing the distance between two points), it will satisfy this question, even if it does not match the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must directly implement the given specification: read one numeric grade between 0 and 100, use conditional logic to determine which range it falls into (A, B, C, D, or F), and print the corresponding letter grade. Solving a different problem, even correctly, does not meet the requirements.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value.
No conditional statements (if/else) to check grade ranges.
Output describes a distance between two points rather than a letter grade.
Variable names and math correspond to coordinate geometry, not grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or examples (e.g., reusing code from a distance-formula exercise) and not carefully aligning the implementation with the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem and rewrite main to: (1) prompt for a single numeric grade, (2) read it into a variable, (3) use if/else-if/else to check the ranges 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, and below 60, and (4) print the correct letter grade. Avoid copying code from unrelated problems.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to program structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every line of the program is dedicated to computing point distance; there is no trace of grade-related logic, so it is almost certain the student implemented the wrong problem.

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinate values, computes Euclidean distance, and prints it, with no mention of grades, ranges, or letter outputs.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points, failing entirely to address the requirement of creating a numeric grade calculator (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code addresses the requirements for Q3, or the student mistakenly submitted code for an entirely different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic (if/else if/else statements) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: The program prompts for four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
The program calculates a Euclidean distance.
The final output is a numerical distance, not a letter grade corresponding to the grading scale.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt, confusing different assignment problems, or submitting the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully review the assignment prompt for Q3: Grade Calculator. The current code calculates distance. You need to implement input reading for one grade, followed by sequential if/else if statements to handle the grading scale (90+ = A, 80-89 = B, etc.) and print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire submitted code addresses a completely different, unrelated classic computational task (distance calculation) than the one assigned (grade calculation).

evidence.note: The code implements distance calculation between two points instead of the required grade calculator logic.

misconceptions.name: Solving wrong problem - distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a distance calculation between two 2D points rather than a grade classification program. This suggests either a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or a copy-paste error from a different problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this program should calculate the Euclidean distance between two coordinate points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade (0-100) and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade
Program uses distance formula: Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1))
No conditional logic for grade ranges
Output is a numeric distance, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Possible confusion between different problem specifications or submission of code from a different assignment
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem specification carefully. The program should: 1) Read ONE numeric grade, 2) Use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, 3) Output the corresponding letter grade
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code performs a completely different computation (distance formula) with no resemblance to the grade classification task. This is unambiguous evidence of solving the wrong problem.

evidence.note: Entire program implements Euclidean distance calculation, not grade classification

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The student has not implemented any if-else statements or conditional logic to check grade ranges. The program proceeds linearly without any branching based on the grade value.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a grade calculator doesn't need conditional statements, or perhaps hasn't implemented the grade checking logic yet.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A grade calculator must use if-else statements (or switch) to check which range the grade falls into and output the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: No if-else statements in the code
No comparison operators checking grade ranges (>= <=)
Program performs linear computation instead of branching logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Either incomplete implementation or misunderstanding of how to implement conditional grade ranges
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add if-else statements: if (grade >= 90) { output 'A'; } else if (grade >= 80) { output 'B'; } and so on for C, D, and F ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Complete absence of any conditional logic in a program that explicitly requires grade range checking is definitive evidence.

evidence.note: No if-else or switch statements present; entire main method is sequential

misconceptions.name: Program does not implement the requested grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of implementing the required grade-to-letter conversion using conditionals.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read a single numeric grade from 0–100, use conditional statements to determine which grade range it falls into, and then print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade.
No if/else or conditional logic is used to check grade ranges.
Output is 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the problem statement or reuse of code from a different exercise involving distance between two points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the question and list the exact inputs and outputs it describes. Replace the coordinate variables with a single grade variable, remove the distance formula, and add an if/else-if/else chain that checks the given grade intervals and prints the correct letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program solves a different, standard textbook problem (distance between two points) and contains no elements of a grade calculator.

evidence.note: All input/output and computation are about the distance between two points; there is no grade input or letter-grade logic.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misunderstanding of Assigned Task
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for an entirely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this submission addresses the required assignment, or perhaps submitted code from a previous assignment by mistake.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires implementing logic to read a single integer grade and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and print a letter grade based on defined ranges (90+, 80-89, etc.).
symptoms: The code asks for 'x1 and y1' and 'x2 and y2' instead of 'Enter grade'.
The code uses Math.sqrt and performs distance calculation instead of grade checking logic.
The final output prints 'The distance of the two points is...' not 'Letter grade: ...'
misconceptions.root_cause: Major confusion regarding the assignment requirements, potentially misreading the prompt, submitting the wrong file, or lacking understanding of how to connect a problem description to a programming solution structure.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the assignment prompt, 'Q3. Grade Calculator,' and focus solely on implementing the specified grading logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure, variable names (x1, y1, x2, y2, d), input prompts, and calculations clearly and unambiguously match the distance formula problem, which is completely irrelevant to the Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: This entire block of code calculates point distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (distance calculator between two points) rather than the assigned grade calculator problem. This indicates either a fundamental misunderstanding of the problem requirements, copying code from a different assignment, or failure to read the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they need to calculate the Euclidean distance between two coordinate pairs using the formula sqrt((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specific ranges: A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), F (below 60).
symptoms: Program reads 4 double values instead of 1 integer
Program outputs a distance calculation instead of a letter grade
No conditional logic (if-else statements) for grade ranges
Uses Math.sqrt() and coordinate distance formula instead of range checking
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either read the wrong problem statement, confused this assignment with another problem (distance calculator), copied code from an unrelated assignment, or failed to read the problem requirements carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement. You need to: (1) Read ONE integer grade value, (2) Use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) Output the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty. The code implements a completely different algorithm (distance formula) and reads completely different input (4 coordinates instead of 1 grade). This is unambiguously the wrong problem.

evidence.note: Reads 4 coordinate values and applies the Euclidean distance formula. The problem requires reading a single grade value and checking it against letter grade ranges.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Outputs a distance calculation. Should output a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
No conditional logic (if-else statements) present in the code. The entire problem requires multiple conditional branches to check grade ranges.
